p.s: Amir is one of the protagonists in the play Disgraced, Scene 3.
In the following his behavior, attitudes and interaction with others is going to be analyzed.
Amir is married to Emily and works at a law firm.
He is a muslimMuslim, but eats porks sometimes.
He didn't mentioned his religion to his employeemployer due discrimination and said his name is indianIndian.
During the whole extract from scene 3 he ia angry and nearly vicious.
This anger goes back to a situation at work (l. 15).
Secondly, he is confused, because doesn't get whatswhat's going on between Isaac and Jory (l. 27).
Amir is still furious about the conflict about Jory being partner at work.
Amir doesn't really listen to the accusations of Jory about the affair.
He believes Emily and blames Jory full of anger (ll. 18-19) and calls her evil.
This describes his trust in Emily and his priority about work.
Furthermore his behaviour underlines his anger.
He doesn't complain about his private matters and the affair.
Moreover, he rages about his hardworking to just get disappointed.
He complains about his work and how Jory didn't had to work so hard for her office and position (ll. 22-29).
He ends his rage by a racial and badly insult against her (l. 29).
His response to Isaac embraces that Amir hates Isaac and can't stand him (ll. 35-37).
AmirsAmir's anger shows when he spits in IsaacsIsaac's face.
This shows his furious behaviour and unpredictable actions (l. 40).
After Isaac leaves, his wife Jory makes Amir furious again.
She provocesprovokes him.
She adressesaddresses that she didn't just got partner, she also takes over MortsMort's caseload.
Amir seems so shocked and vulnerable, that he doesn't even reply anymore (ll. 3-13).
Even thothough his wife tries to calm him, he is still furious and angry about the situation.
This shows by his nervous spirals and his back and forth walking while being withdrawn (ll. 16-17).
After he was left alone for a few moments, because his wife Emily got him a coffecoffee, he finally askasks her about the affair (l. 27).
He calls her by her nickname and seems vulnerable as he askesasks her.
This shows that he does care about the affair, but maybe didn't want it to be real (ll. 25-26).
After Emily confesses the whole story about London and Isaac and she outlines how disgusting she is (ll. 31-4) Amir doesn't say anything, but her words make him so furious that he beats her.
He gets so agressiveaggressive that he doesn't stop after one blow.
He goes on one after another.
He puts all his anger into beating her (ll. 6-14).
After his angry outburst he relizesrealizes what he has done to her and is scared about himself and shocked (l. 15).
Alltogether, Amir is a badly developing protagonist.
He wasn't friendly and honest to his co-worker Jory, he didn't like Isaac and thinks he is annoying and even to his wife he is cruel.
He can't control himself and just lets his uncontrolled violence and anger out by beating his wife.
In this scene he isn't likablelikeable and seems really agressiveaggressive to the reader.
